commit_message:
Support definition of non-default home dir path

For deployments where the network environment uses NIS and NFS,
it is necessary to use a non-default location for home directories
for local users such as the kayobe ansible user.

Change-Id: I898ef7daa96ce501587fd54ca1088ea0c062497d

messages: [{'account_id': 31245, 'date': '2019-11-14 14:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-11-14 14:07:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-14 14:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\n@hberaud Feel free to just fast approve these if there are any more :)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 14:06:11.000000000', 'message': "Stop configuring install_command in tox.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: Ibcdd3a9f7e7ea421e906cf1d96f95b516008b5d7
"}]
commit_message:
Stop configuring install_command in tox.

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: Ibcdd3a9f7e7ea421e906cf1d96f95b516008b5d7

commit_message:
Allows to use application credentials through group membership

When using role assignment through groups, the user cannot use
the application credentials created. This allows to look up
the membership by checking inherited and group assignments.

Conflicts:
    This change conflicts with newer branches because most of the
    logic in keystone/token/providers/common.py was refactored into
    keystone/models/token_model.py during the Rocky release. This
    refactor causes the stable/queens version to diverge from
    stable/rocky, stable/stein, and stable/train patches, although it
    is functionally equivalent to the approach used in later releases.

Change-Id: If1bf5bd785a494923303265797311d42018ba7af
Closes-Bug: #1773967
(cherry picked from commit 14b25bc5d18842210cfffe1afdca475e848b84aa)
(cherry picked from commit 933ea511d150ed2cbbd4265fc7513a9b3435baa2)
(cherry picked from commit cf83fc10569e7b52eeb52c0e164dfe36daeec309)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-08 15:48:17.000000000', 'message': 'doc: fix and clarify --block-device usage in user docs

The docs on create a volume-backed server from the command
line were wrong in a few ways:

* The openstack server create command does not currently allow
  booting from a volume where a source image is provided and
  nova creates the volume from the image and uses that volume
  as the root disk. The nova boot command supports that, so the
  docs are updated to call out the nova boot command since that
  is the appropriate command in this case (even the syntax with
  the openstack server create --block-device was wrong).

* When creating a server from a bootable volume with the OSC CLI,
  either the --volume or --block-device options should be used
  for a single volume, but not both. The docs were using both, so
  the latter is dropped and a note is added which links to the CLI
  documentation for more details on --block-device option usage.

Change-Id: I985b870759d6c21ef9357b04f39099c02354f135
Closes-Bug: #1794827
(cherry picked from commit 16027094ebabc5cd9f2e766431f18aadeff54a40)
'}, {'created': '2019-11-08 15:49:29.000000000', 'message': 'doc: fix and clarify --block-device usage in user docs

The docs on create a volume-backed server from the command
line were wrong in a few ways:

* The openstack server create command does not currently allow

  as the root disk. The nova boot command supports that, so the
  docs are updated to call out the nova boot command since that
  is the appropriate command in this case (even the syntax with
  the openstack server create --block-device was wrong).

* When creating a server from a bootable volume with the OSC CLI,

  for a single volume, but not both. The docs were using both, so
  the latter is dropped and a note is added which links to the CLI
  documentation for more details on --block-device option usage.

Change-Id: I985b870759d6c21ef9357b04f39099c02354f135
Closes-Bug: #1794827
(cherry picked from commit 16027094ebabc5cd9f2e766431f18aadeff54a40)
'}]
commit_message:
doc: fix and clarify --block-device usage in user docs

The docs on create a volume-backed server from the command
line were wrong in a few ways:

* The openstack server create command does not currently allow
  booting from a volume where a source image is provided and
  nova creates the volume from the image and uses that volume
  as the root disk. The nova boot command supports that, so the
  docs are updated to call out the nova boot command since that
  is the appropriate command in this case (even the syntax with
  the openstack server create --block-device was wrong).

* When creating a server from a bootable volume with the OSC CLI,
  either the --volume or --block-device options should be used
  for a single volume, but not both. The docs were using both, so
  the latter is dropped and a note is added which links to the CLI
  documentation for more details on --block-device option usage.

Change-Id: I985b870759d6c21ef9357b04f39099c02354f135
Closes-Bug: #1794827
(cherry picked from commit 16027094ebabc5cd9f2e766431f18aadeff54a40)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-23 06:52:49.000000000', 'message': "add X.509 certificate check plugin

Currently we don't have any capability to monitor the internal TLS/SSL
certificates. i.e. SSL certificates used by MySQL for replication, RabbitMQ for
distribution, etc. The cert_check plugin is not adequate for this purpose
becaue it can only check on certficates over HTTPS endpoints. Furthermore,
checking on these internal certificates over the network is cumbersome
because the agent plugin would have to speak specific protocols.

This patch adds a cert_file_check plugin to detect the certificate expiry
(in days from now) for the given X.509 certificate file in PEM format.
Similar to cert_check plugin, this plugin will a metric
'cert_file.cert_expire_days' which contains the number of days from now the
given certificate will be expired. If the certificate has already expired,
this will be a negative number.

Change-Id: Id95cc7115823f972e234417223ab5906b57447cc
Story: 2006753

commit_message:
add X.509 certificate check plugin

Currently we don't have any capability to monitor the internal TLS/SSL
certificates. i.e. SSL certificates used by MySQL for replication, RabbitMQ for
distribution, etc. The cert_check plugin is not adequate for this purpose
becaue it can only check on certficates over HTTPS endpoints. Furthermore,
checking on these internal certificates over the network is cumbersome
because the agent plugin would have to speak specific protocols.

This patch adds a cert_file_check plugin to detect the certificate expiry
(in days from now) for the given X.509 certificate file in PEM format.
Similar to cert_check plugin, this plugin will a metric
'cert_file.cert_expire_days' which contains the number of days from now the
given certificate will be expired. If the certificate has already expired,
this will be a negative number.

Change-Id: Id95cc7115823f972e234417223ab5906b57447cc
Story: 2006753

messages:
[{'account_id': 30571, 'date': '2019-06-11 02:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-06-11 02:06:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30571, 'date': '2019-06-12 01:19:25.000000000', 'content': 'Topic like removed'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-06-14 13:56:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Glad to have you contributing. :)

The commit message is a little short.  Do you mind describing why we want to just add cassandra to ARG EXTRA_DEPS rather than finding a way to optionally switch between influx and cassandra?  I'm not the Dockerfile expert, so I wonder if just including it will grow the image size.

Also, it would help to have a story in https://storyboard.openstack.org to tie this and the matching change in monasca-persister together.  Once there is a story in storyboard, you can include the number in the commit message like
 
Story: 12345"}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2019-07-01 13:24:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2019-07-02 12:28:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Do you mind describing why
 > we want to just add cassandra to ARG EXTRA_DEPS rather than finding
 > a way to optionally switch between influx and cassandra?  I'm not
 > the Dockerfile expert, so I wonder if just including it will grow
 > the image size.

Finding way to optionally switching between influx and cassandra would mean to build two images because we don't want to install anything from pip at the container start.

And testing now turns out that installing cassandra-driver add additional ~ 50 MB to docker image (up from 158 MB to 205MB). That's a lot and I'm actually considering if it would be better to build and provide two separate containers..."}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-07-02 12:39:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> And testing now turns out that installing cassandra-driver add
 > additional ~ 50 MB to docker image (up from 158 MB to 205MB).
 > That's a lot and I'm actually considering if it would be better to
 > build and provide two separate containers...

I think, I like this idea."}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2019-11-13 14:17:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2019-11-13 14:18:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > And testing now turns out that installing cassandra-driver add
 > > additional ~ 50 MB to docker image (up from 158 MB to 205MB).
 > > That's a lot and I'm actually considering if it would be better
 > to
 > > build and provide two separate containers...
 > 
 > I think, I like this idea.

+ 1"}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-11-14 16:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

How should we proceed with this? I think building a separate image for Cassandra is the preferred approach.

Li, do you want to continue the work on this? Do you need some guidance?'}]

commit_message:
Make mask_password case insensitive, and add new patterns

It appears that Mistral service logs everything, and doesn't use yet
the mask_password (nor mask_dict_password) method. In order to ensure
all is properly masked, we have to add some new patterns, and make it
case insensitive in order to simplify and avoid duplicated entries.

Change-Id: Icc19b7c8bdb6a3182939d5e9fdef21288b19f43d
Related-Bug: #1850843
Signed-off-by: Cédric Jeanneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit b41268417cecb12d1d5955ee3107067edf050221)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 12:22:24.000000000', 'message': "DNM: python3 experiments

I think this might be failing because the 'install_ceph_remote' function
provided by the 'devstack-plugin-ceph' plugin installs the 'ceph-common'
package [1], which installs all the python, not python3, variants of
various packages [2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph/blob/1c9e3e772e555589d6a31b718dd9d7eda6cfa63b/devstack/lib/ceph#L963-L965
[2] https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/ceph-common

We can merge this back in once we figure out whether it helps or not.

Change-Id: Ib3092cb421ef35e0343eed0108e7dabebbe439df
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
DNM: python3 experiments

I think this might be failing because the 'install_ceph_remote' function
provided by the 'devstack-plugin-ceph' plugin installs the 'ceph-common'
package [1], which installs all the python, not python3, variants of
various packages [2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph/blob/1c9e3e772e555589d6a31b718dd9d7eda6cfa63b/devstack/lib/ceph#L963-L965
[2] https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/ceph-common

We can merge this back in once we figure out whether it helps or not.

Change-Id: Ib3092cb421ef35e0343eed0108e7dabebbe439df
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 09:55:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed

Backport: Stein, Rocky, Queens

In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671502/ kolla ansible virtualenv
creation was modified to only happen on hosts in the kolla-ansible
inventory. However, that change omitted the seed. It passed CI because
the seed and overcloud are both in the inventory.

This change adds the seed group to the inventory_hostname lookup.

Change-Id: Ib5fb726600debee5df1f7085ea37b583bfccefcf
Story: 2006247
Task: 37368
(cherry picked from commit e4f8a5de8e90abcf7084712848f47cbf3262d6bf)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed

Backport: Stein, Rocky, Queens

In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671502/ kolla ansible virtualenv
creation was modified to only happen on hosts in the kolla-ansible
inventory. However, that change omitted the seed. It passed CI because
the seed and overcloud are both in the inventory.

This change adds the seed group to the inventory_hostname lookup.

Change-Id: Ib5fb726600debee5df1f7085ea37b583bfccefcf
Story: 2006247
Task: 37368
(cherry picked from commit e4f8a5de8e90abcf7084712848f47cbf3262d6bf)

commit_message:
Remove dead set_admin_password code to generate password

The schema validation on the changePassword server action API
requires adminPass as a non-None string value so the code
down in the ComputeManager.set_admin_password method to check
if new_pass is None and generate a password if so is dead code
and is removed here along with the password=None kwarg usage
in the API.

Change-Id: I310df11043f8bfe78640087d9ec2848ace65edc8

[{'created': '2019-11-12 21:16:34.000000000', 'message': 'Make API always RPC cast to conductor for resize/migrate

This is a follow up to [1] to make the API behave consistently
by always asynchronously casting to conductor during resize
and cold migration regardless of same-cell or cross-cell
migration.

From the end user point of view, not much changes besides
the possibility of some exceptions occurring during scheduling
which would have resulted in a 400 BadRequest error.
The user still gets a 202 response, must poll the server status
until the server goes to VERIFY_RESIZE status or times out, and
can check the instance actions if the resize/migrate fails.

The specific errors that can occur are not really an API contract
and as such end user applications should not be building logic
around, for example, getting a NoValidHost error. It should be
noted, however, that by default non-admin users cannot see
the instance action event traceback that would contain the
error, e.g. NoValidHost.

The only exception types removed from handling in the API are
(1) AllocationMoveFailed which can be raised when the conductor
MigrationTask runs replace_allocation_with_migration and
(2) NoValidHost when the scheduler is called to select destinations.

Because of this, quite a few functional negative tests have to be
adjusted since the API no longer returns a 400 for NoValidHost and
other errors that can happen during scheduling.

[1] I098f91d8c498e5a85266e193ad37c08aca4792b2

Change-Id: I711e56bcb4b72605253fa63be230a68e03e45b84

The only exception types removed from handling in the API are
(1) AllocationMoveFailed which can be raised when the conductor
MigrationTask runs replace_allocation_with_migration and
(2) NoValidHost when the scheduler is called to select destinations.

Because of this, quite a few functional negative tests have to be
adjusted since the API no longer returns a 400 for NoValidHost and
other errors that can happen during scheduling.

Finally, the do_cast kwarg is left on the conductor API method since
the compute service calls it during same-cell reschedule as a

commit_message:
Make API always RPC cast to conductor for resize/migrate

This is a follow up to [1] to make the API behave consistently
by always asynchronously casting to conductor during resize
and cold migration regardless of same-cell or cross-cell
migration.

From the end user point of view, not much changes besides
the possibility of some exceptions occurring during scheduling
which would have resulted in a 400 BadRequest error.
The user still gets a 202 response, must poll the server status
until the server goes to VERIFY_RESIZE status or times out, and
can check the instance actions if the resize/migrate fails.

The specific errors that can occur are not really an API contract
and as such end user applications should not be building logic
around, for example, getting a NoValidHost error. It should be
noted, however, that by default non-admin users cannot see
the instance action event traceback that would contain the
error, e.g. NoValidHost.

The only exception types removed from handling in the API are
(1) AllocationMoveFailed which can be raised when the conductor
MigrationTask runs replace_allocation_with_migration and
(2) NoValidHost when the scheduler is called to select destinations.

Because of this, quite a few functional negative tests have to be
adjusted since the API no longer returns a 400 for NoValidHost and
other errors that can happen during scheduling.

Finally, the do_cast kwarg is left on the conductor API method since
the compute service calls it during same-cell reschedule as a
synchronous RPC call and has error handling if rescheduling in
conductor fails.

[1] I098f91d8c498e5a85266e193ad37c08aca4792b2

Change-Id: I711e56bcb4b72605253fa63be230a68e03e45b84

commit_message:
Add extra unit test for get_cmdline_from_pid function

In patch [1] get_cmdline_from_pid function was modified to be able
to parse process' cmdline files with arguments separated by space
instead of '\0' char.
This patch adds one extra UT and small refactor which was pointed
in comments to [1] but which I was not able to change there.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/647605/

Change-Id: Ibd91d0472a686eca79a1126154d9cdf4587c1a19
Related-Bug: #1820870

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 09:52:47.000000000', 'message': 'Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed

Backport: Stein, Rocky, Queens

In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671502/ kolla ansible virtualenv
creation was modified to only happen on hosts in the kolla-ansible
inventory. However, that change omitted the seed. It passed CI because
the seed and overcloud are both in the inventory.

This change adds the seed group to the inventory_hostname lookup.

Change-Id: Ib5fb726600debee5df1f7085ea37b583bfccefcf
Story: 2006247
Task: 37368
(cherry picked from commit e4f8a5de8e90abcf7084712848f47cbf3262d6bf)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed

Backport: Stein, Rocky, Queens

In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671502/ kolla ansible virtualenv
creation was modified to only happen on hosts in the kolla-ansible
inventory. However, that change omitted the seed. It passed CI because
the seed and overcloud are both in the inventory.

This change adds the seed group to the inventory_hostname lookup.

Change-Id: Ib5fb726600debee5df1f7085ea37b583bfccefcf
Story: 2006247
Task: 37368
(cherry picked from commit e4f8a5de8e90abcf7084712848f47cbf3262d6bf)

subject: Only set up the kolla ansible venv on hosts in the kolla ansible inventory

[{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-11-04 14:25:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-11-05 11:17:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

While looking at this change again, I noticed that the default host limit is "seed:overcloud". With this patch the playbook will never run on the seed?

Also, kolla-target-venv is called by SeedHypervisorHostUpgrade, but the playbook is limited to seed:overcloud (that's probably an issue with the code in SeedHypervisorHostUpgrade).'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-11-05 11:39:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This patch replaces git.openstack.org with opendev.org as redirection
from old path was enabled.
Also we change upper constraints url due to [1]

commit_message:
Move base policies into code

This commit attempts to move the base rules for glance's policy into
code.  Subsequent patches will continue to move the rest of glance's
policy into code and remove the definitions from etc/policy.json.

bp policy-and-docs-in-code

Change-Id: I5fa65b8421351c8b6dfc2dcb10af4ec7c322bda1

[{'created': '2019-11-06 09:39:44.000000000', 'message': "Use python -m pip instead pip command.

It's recommand to use this way. With tox is not really necessary to do
it but it can be good to use it. See this article:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

For example python -m pip executes pip using the Python interpreter
you specified as python.

Change-Id: I8b71e762b5ce5ee0f9ffa594715a21677ded55f3
"}, {'created': '2019-11-07 14:06:49.000000000', 'message': "Use python -m pip instead pip command.

It's recommand to use this way. With tox is not really necessary to do
it but it can be good to use it. See this article:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

For example python -m pip executes pip using the Python interpreter

Change-Id: I8b71e762b5ce5ee0f9ffa594715a21677ded55f3
"}]
commit_message:
Use python -m pip instead pip command.

It's recommand to use this way. With tox is not really necessary to do
it but it can be good to use it. See this article:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

For example python -m pip executes pip using the Python interpreter
you specified as python.

Change-Id: I8b71e762b5ce5ee0f9ffa594715a21677ded55f3

commit_message:
Add support for custom HAProxy service config

Allow users to create/override HAProxy service configuration by
copying over '*.cfg' files from {{ node_custom_config
}}/haproxy/services.d/

Ex: /etc/kolla/config/haproxy/services.d/radosgw.cfg

Change-Id: Id84e3b6e62e544582d6917047534e846e026798d
Signed-off-by: Keith Plant <kplantjr@gmail.com>

Looks like Ia87bf68bdade3e6f7f752d013f4bdb29bfa5d444 broke
neutron_to_osvif_subnet and now lower-constraints gate fails with:

 TypeError: 'Subnet' object has no attribute '__getitem__'

issue.

Change-Id: I3577020b3fb6b91eb99204e5cd15072490532e12
"}]
commit_message:
Bump openstacksdk to 0.17.2

Looks like Ia87bf68bdade3e6f7f752d013f4bdb29bfa5d444 broke
neutron_to_osvif_subnet and now lower-constraints gate fails with:

 TypeError: 'Subnet' object has no attribute '__getitem__'

This commit bumps it to safe Rocky's 0.17.2 in an attempt to fix the
issue.

Change-Id: I3577020b3fb6b91eb99204e5cd15072490532e12

commit_message:
CI: Remove collectd roles

Collectd roles have been used in the past in CI for collecting data
and drawing rrd graphs. It has been disabled since Dec 2018 [1].

[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/65296e27e665a431b786944224195ba7593473bc

Change-Id: If9fbffe3c1753fde2c0e1e9562d664dca03cc02d

subject: Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-11-14 09:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 09:55:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed

Backport: Stein, Rocky, Queens

In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671502/ kolla ansible virtualenv
creation was modified to only happen on hosts in the kolla-ansible
inventory. However, that change omitted the seed. It passed CI because
the seed and overcloud are both in the inventory.

This change adds the seed group to the inventory_hostname lookup.

Change-Id: Ib5fb726600debee5df1f7085ea37b583bfccefcf
Story: 2006247
Task: 37368
(cherry picked from commit e4f8a5de8e90abcf7084712848f47cbf3262d6bf)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix kolla ansible virtualenv creation on the seed

Backport: Stein, Rocky, Queens

In https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671502/ kolla ansible virtualenv
creation was modified to only happen on hosts in the kolla-ansible
inventory. However, that change omitted the seed. It passed CI because
the seed and overcloud are both in the inventory.

This change adds the seed group to the inventory_hostname lookup.

Change-Id: Ib5fb726600debee5df1f7085ea37b583bfccefcf
Story: 2006247
Task: 37368
(cherry picked from commit e4f8a5de8e90abcf7084712848f47cbf3262d6bf)

messages:
[{'account_id': 31268, 'date': '2019-11-12 09:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-11-12 09:46:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-05 12:10:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix keystone fernet rotation for source images

In source images, keystone-manage is installed to a virtualenv in
/var/lib/kolla/venv. This is not in the PATH for cron jobs, which always
use PATH=/usr/bin:/bin. This results in the following error:

/usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh: line 3: keystone-manage: command not found

However this error is not typically visible, since cron logs to syslog
and we do not configure fluentd to collect these logs.

This change configures the PATH in the fernet-rotate.sh script for
source images.

Change-Id: Ib49ea586d36ae32d01b9610a48b13798db4a4cd5
Closes-Bug: #1850711
'}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone fernet rotation for source images

In source images, keystone-manage is installed to a virtualenv in
/var/lib/kolla/venv. This is not in the PATH for cron jobs, which always
use PATH=/usr/bin:/bin. This results in the following error:

/usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh: line 3: keystone-manage: command not found

However this error is not typically visible, since cron logs to syslog
and we do not configure fluentd to collect these logs.

This change configures the PATH in the fernet-rotate.sh script for
source images.

Change-Id: Ib49ea586d36ae32d01b9610a48b13798db4a4cd5
Closes-Bug: #1850711

commit_message:
Configuring ceph-ansible rpm package

In order to gate ceph-ansible on github, we need to add the ceph-ansible
package in the undercloud_rpm_dependences variable. This is required
because of launchpad bug 1841941 that force us to use the ceph-ansible package
ceph-ansible-4.0.0-0.1.rc16.1.
On ceph-ansible githug gate job, with this change, it will install
properly the latest version since is bigger than 4.0.0. In non
ceph-ansible gate jobs, it will work as expected, and install
ceph-ansible 4.0.0

Change-Id: I682d82c8ef095996dad9a78f02b7849933962be9

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-04 12:25:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix execution of custom vs default validations

In some cases, deleted custom validations were being selected
for execution. This is due to the yaml files being found in
/tmp even after they have been deleted from Swift. This patch
fixes that by simply downloading the whole validations container
thus making sure that any stale files get overwritten.

Change-Id: Ib65d318c527dbe55693860eb367677a58c68a9a1
Story: 2003624
'}, {'created': '2018-11-09 08:57:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fix execution of custom vs default validations

In some cases, deleted custom validations were being selected
for execution. This is due to the yaml files being found in
/tmp even after they have been deleted from Swift. This patch
fixes that by simply downloading the whole validations container
thus making sure that any stale files get overwritten.

Change-Id: Ib65d318c527dbe55693860eb367677a58c68a9a1
Story: 2003624
'}, {'created': '2019-04-08 12:35:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix execution of custom vs default validations

In some cases, deleted custom validations were being selected
for execution. This is due to the yaml files being found in
/tmp even after they have been deleted from Swift. This patch
fixes that by simply downloading the whole validations container
thus making sure that any stale files get overwritten.

commit_message:
Fix execution of custom vs default validations

In some cases, deleted custom validations were being selected
for execution. This is due to the yaml files being found in
/tmp even after they have been deleted from Swift. This patch
fixes that by simply downloading the whole validations container
thus making sure that any stale files get overwritten.

Change-Id: Ib65d318c527dbe55693860eb367677a58c68a9a1
Story: 2003624

commit_message:
Stop converting Migration objects to dicts for migrate_instance_start

The Migration object has the NovaObjectDictCompat mixin so we can
just pass the Migration object directly to the migrate_instance_start
method and it works like a dict so this change removes the unnecessary
obj_to_primitive conversion in a couple of spots. Apparently there were
no tests that actually cared about that conversion either.

Long-term the migrate_instance_start method should enfroce that an
object is passed rather than a dict but that's a much bigger effort
left for another day.

Change-Id: I1b7657b450676cd537b4afaf6773e940f65314a6

commit_message:
Require Migration object arg to migrate_instance_finish method

There is one place in the compute manager that is passing a dict
for the migration to the migrate_instance_finish method but a
Migration object should be passed. The dict works because the
Migration object uses the NovaObjectDictCompat mixin but that is
something we'd like to eventually remove since it's nice to know
if you're dealing with an object or a dict.

This converts the remaining uses of migrate_instance_finish that
were using a dict for the migration over to using an object.

Change-Id: Ice8b167d6fe026e7043a0899f399a62e25dcfcd1

commit_message:
Stop configuring 'install_command'

Currently, we are overriding 'install_command' to use 'pip'. This is
considered poor behavior and 'python -m pip' should be used instead.

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

It turns out that this is the the default value provided by tox:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-install_command

So we can remove the line and simply use the default value.

Change-Id: I591475707205732e68e3e68231c417acf672277b

commit_message:
Fix get min interval error

When we use get_min_interval method, the exit condition is
the execution time is bigger than the rate time. But default
minutes rate is 2, this may leads errors when the interval
is bigger than 2 minutes, it always return None. So we can
not use min interval to judge if the interval is smaller than
that we configured in the configuration file. This should be
fixed.
Story: 2006848
Task: 37436

[{'created': '2019-10-25 20:44:39.000000000', 'message': 'doc: add troubleshooting guide for cleaning up orphaned allocations

While we do not have an automated fix for bug 1849479 this provides
a troubleshooting document for working around that issue where
allocations from a server that was evacuated from a down host need
to be cleaned up manually in order to delete the resource provider
and associated compute node/service.

In general this is also a useful guide for linking up the various
resources and terms in nova and how they are reflected in placement
with the relevant commands which is probably something we should
do more of in our docs.

Related-Bug: #1829479

commit_message:
doc: add troubleshooting guide for cleaning up orphaned allocations

While we do not have an automated fix for bug 1849479 this provides
a troubleshooting document for working around that issue where
allocations from a server that was evacuated from a down host need
to be cleaned up manually in order to delete the resource provider
and associated compute node/service.

In general this is also a useful guide for linking up the various
resources and terms in nova and how they are reflected in placement
with the relevant commands which is probably something we should
do more of in our docs.

Change-Id: I120e1ddd7946a371888bfc890b5979f2e19288cd
Related-Bug: #1829479

commit_message:
Fix bug for running unittest with unittest module

When we run unittest with a way like:
python -m unittest2 <test_file>
then NoSuchOptError exception will raised

Change-Id: Ib0f9276c1b86ff7f2d1e401ddfae2bf4e920fa78

commit_message:
Add component_ci_containers in build-containers for component ci

As part of [1] we need to override the list of containers built
by the build-containers role. This adds a component_ci_containers
parameter that is passed by the job at [2]. This sets the
containers file added here for the compute component (it was
initially at [3] but moved here after initial discussion).

[1] https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1378
[2] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/23655
[3] https://review.opendev.org/692840

Change-Id: I60a8cc66c439cbae7b8697a8279996ff82cd4375

[{'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-15 02:05:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-15 02:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to drop-python2-support'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-10-15 16:57:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(2 comments)

Dropping python2 support from keystone needs to be coordinated with the rest of the OpenStack community, especially given keystone's central role in an OpenStack deployment. The TC has outlined a draft plan and will be having a meeting on this next week:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

I'm placing an administrative -2 on this until that meeting happens and we get clarification on the coordinated community-wide plan. In the mean time, I have left -1-worthy comments inline on the commit message that could be addressed."}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-16 02:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-16 05:44:31.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-10-24 20:52:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

There's now a coordinated plan and it looks like we should go ahead and drop the python2 jobs: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010356.html

Could you update this change to actually drop those jobs in .zuul.yaml, and modify the commit message to reference that email and not plagiarize Stephen's commit message?"}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-25 07:28:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-10-29 19:22:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Still some functional tests using python2'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-29 19:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

also can you add a releasenotes also

Python 2.7 support has been dropped. Last release of Keystone to support
   py2.7 is OpenStack Train. The minimum version of Python now
   supported by Keystone is Python 3.6.'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-30 02:59:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-30 03:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-10-30 06:15:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Still no releasenotes.'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-30 06:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-10-30 07:55:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

You need to drop this [1] since python 2.7 support is removed.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/doc/requirements.txt#L5'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-30 08:40:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-30 11:33:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I think you need to remove the `six` usages too

https://github.com/openstack/keystone/search?q=six&unscoped_q=six

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-30 12:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(6 comments)

> I think you need to remove the `six` usages too
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/keystone/search?q=six&unscoped_q=six
 > 
 > Thoughts?

Six is a Python 2 and 3 compatibility library, there is no need to remove it in this patch.

Consdering performance, we could remove it in other Code Review Request, but not this.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-10-30 15:49:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

> (6 comments)
 > 
 > > I think you need to remove the `six` usages too
 > >
 > > https://github.com/openstack/keystone/search?q=six&unscoped_q=six
 > >
 > > Thoughts?
 > 
 > Six is a Python 2 and 3 compatibility library, there is no need to
 > remove it in this patch.
 > 
 > Consdering performance, we could remove it in other Code Review
 > Request, but not this.

I agree with this. If anything, that should happen separately so that this patch, which is just about dropping the CI, remains easy to review. Even as a separate patch, however, I would prefer we do not go through the entire codebase and rip out compatibility code, it's a waste of contributors' and reviewers' time.

requirements check needs to be fixed, some more minor notes inline."}, {'account_id': 30395, 'date': '2019-10-31 06:19:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-10-31 08:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-15 02:05:57.000000000', 'message': "Stop testing Python 2

It's Ussuri. We can *finally* stop testing Python 2 [1].
We don't attempt any cleanup but simply stop testing with Python 2,
indicating that we only support Python 3 via 'setup.cfg' and remove any
Python 2 only dependencies. The 'tox.ini' is modified such that
'functional' now runs with 'python3'

This should free up a significant amount of resources from the gate and
let us start using Python 3 idioms in our code.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html#python2-deprecation-timeline

Change-Id: I35e871992dd21e96e7e812e440e6cafdb61d26ac

commit_message:
Stop testing Python 2

In Ussuri, Drop support for Python 2 according to [1] and [2]

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010356.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html

Change-Id: I35e871992dd21e96e7e812e440e6cafdb61d26ac

This has not merged to master and has not been properly cherry-picked. You need to wait for patches to merge to the more recent branches before you propose them to older ones.

If you use the Gerrit UI and cherry-pick on change that has not merged, it does not include the required information in the commit message (and it might not be what ultimately gets merged to the later branch). commit_message:
Fix VxFlexOS documentation

Remove unnecessary instructions for containerized deployment
using VxFlex OS driver. Old instructions are not working and
will not be applicable after the bug will be resolved.

Change-Id: I16319ab394e75cbe5d8898afcb1d1043f898f315
Closes-Bug: #1846483
(cherry picked from commit 6271bb316b389a69780c3b8cc8d1a78caefc74b7)

 > to be thorough seeing as this is inline to object PUTs.

Make sure to not be limited by the object-server during your bench. Still, you should at least see the jiffies improvement."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-11-07 08:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2019-11-07 10:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-11-07 23:30:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

LGTM! I'll let Matt finish his testing though."}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-11-13 06:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Spend some time running some basic benchmarks: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/swift-remove-prxy-queues-benchmarks

Note this was done on a SAIO on a shared tenanted cloud, so some numbers may skew. But all in all it looks awesome.

Nice work Romain!'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2019-11-13 13:35:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-06 04:14:01.000000000', 'message': "proxy: stop sending chunks to objects with a Queue

During a PUT of an object, the proxy instanciates one Putter per
object-server that will store data (either the full object or a
fragment, depending on the storage policy). Each Putter is owning a
Queue that will be used to bufferize data chunks before they are
written to the socket connected to the object-server. The chunks are
moved from the queue to the socket by a greenthread. There is one
greenthread per Putter. If the client is uploading faster than the
object-servers can manage, the Queue could grow and consume a lot of
memory. To avoid that, the queue is bounded (default: 10). Having a
bounded queue also allows to ensure that all object-servers will get
the data at the same rate because if one queue is full, the
greenthread reading from the client socket will block when trying to
write to the queue. So the global rate is the one of the slowest
object-server.

The thing is, every operating system manages socket buffers for incoming
and outgoing data. Concerning the send buffer, the behavior is such that
if the buffer is full, a call to write() will block, otherwise the call
will return immediately. It behaves a lot like the Putter's Queue,
except that the size of the buffer is dynamic so it adapts itself to the
speed of the receiver.

Thus, managing a queue in addition to the socket send buffer is a
duplicate queueing/buffering that provides no interest but is, as shown
by profiling and benchmarks, very CPU costly.

This patch removes the queuing mecanism. Instead, the greenthread
reading data from the client will directly write to the socket. If an
object-server is getting slow, the buffer will fulfill, blocking the
reader greenthread. Benchmark shows a CPU consumption reduction of more
than 30% will the observed rate for an upload is increasing by about
45%.

Change-Id: Icf8f800cb25096f93d3faa1e6ec091eb29500758

commit_message:
proxy: stop sending chunks to objects with a Queue

During a PUT of an object, the proxy instanciates one Putter per
object-server that will store data (either the full object or a
fragment, depending on the storage policy). Each Putter is owning a
Queue that will be used to bufferize data chunks before they are
written to the socket connected to the object-server. The chunks are
moved from the queue to the socket by a greenthread. There is one
greenthread per Putter. If the client is uploading faster than the
object-servers can manage, the Queue could grow and consume a lot of
memory. To avoid that, the queue is bounded (default: 10). Having a
bounded queue also allows to ensure that all object-servers will get
the data at the same rate because if one queue is full, the
greenthread reading from the client socket will block when trying to
write to the queue. So the global rate is the one of the slowest
object-server.

The thing is, every operating system manages socket buffers for incoming
and outgoing data. Concerning the send buffer, the behavior is such that
if the buffer is full, a call to write() will block, otherwise the call
will return immediately. It behaves a lot like the Putter's Queue,
except that the size of the buffer is dynamic so it adapts itself to the
speed of the receiver.

Thus, managing a queue in addition to the socket send buffer is a
duplicate queueing/buffering that provides no interest but is, as shown
by profiling and benchmarks, very CPU costly.

This patch removes the queuing mecanism. Instead, the greenthread
reading data from the client will directly write to the socket. If an
object-server is getting slow, the buffer will fulfill, blocking the
reader greenthread. Benchmark shows a CPU consumption reduction of more
than 30% will the observed rate for an upload is increasing by about
45%.

Change-Id: Icf8f800cb25096f93d3faa1e6ec091eb29500758

commit_message:
Create train branch for os_murano role

As Murano has been merged after branching, but was announced and
OSA is lagging behind, it's probably worth to branch murano
for train.

Change-Id: I7334d1671410160df9f235a53af6c7dbade7a96c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-11 09:18:44.000000000', 'message': "Use python -m pip instead pip command.

It's recommand to use this way. With tox is not really necessary to do
it but it can be good to use it. See this article:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

For example python -m pip executes pip using the Python interpreter
you specified as python.

Change-Id: Icf90d76eb51c4a52c2cfda0f51f64697bd5cfdb9
"}]
commit_message:
Use python -m pip instead pip command.

It's recommand to use this way. With tox is not really necessary to do
it but it can be good to use it. See this article:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

For example python -m pip executes pip using the Python interpreter
you specified as python.

Change-Id: Icf90d76eb51c4a52c2cfda0f51f64697bd5cfdb9

commit_message:
Fix overcloud cell export after refactoring

https://review.opendev.org/692909 introduced overcloud export and
refactored the overcloud cell export command which introduces an
issue when calling the cell export:

  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_cell.py",
line 94, in take_action
    data['parameter_defaults'].update(export.export_stack(
KeyError: 'parameter_defaults'
'parameter_defaults'

Change-Id: Ic6b76e31885d0e0b59a650dbd4148b245f6057d6
Closes-Bug: #1852402
Related-Bug: #1850636

commit_message:
Network traffic distributor

The patch add a spec to describe how to implement the network traffic
distributor, ts functions similar to ECMP, But it is simpler to use than
ECMP, and it has no single point failure.

Use network traffic distributor, the users can implement a three-layer
load balancer.

Implements: blueprint network-traffic-distributor
Change-Id: I8ddb1cd0efb81a86f174f5e3729ff99dfaf370b1

[{'created': '2018-07-02 00:57:20.000000000', 'message': 'Segment Range Management of Self-service Networks

Currently, segment ranges were nothing more than an entry in a config
file that was statically defined for tenant network allocation [1].
Neutron type drivers parse the segment ranges pre-defined in the host
configuration. And it is not able to modify them once the services have
been initialized.

This specs introduces an extension which exposes the management of
segment ranges to the api user. Now the user can manage them as they
would like to for tenant networks.

commit_message:
Segment Range Management of Self-service Networks

Currently, segment ranges were nothing more than an entry in a config
file that was statically defined for tenant network allocation [1].
Neutron type drivers parse the segment ranges pre-defined in the host
configuration. And it is not able to modify them once the services have
been initialized.

This specs introduces an extension which exposes the management of
segment ranges to the api user. Now the user can manage them as they
would like to for tenant networks.

[1] /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini

Implements: blueprint segment-range-mgmt-of-tenant-networks
Change-Id: Ide7b52898b9f802e840e265f880643678d0717c9
Signed-off-by: Kailun Qin <kailun.qin@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add a 'promiscuous mode' extension for ports

This spec intro add a field into port resource, and according to the value
to control the vm port running in promiscuous mode or not.
The mode can be changed through port updating call.

Co-Authored-By: Hongbin Lu <hongbin034@gmail.com>

APIImpact
DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1525824
Change-Id: I9d965eebf4d6b7514dd56181f0a85eed3e6e12c6

[{'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-23 02:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-23 02:50:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-08-23 20:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think this is a very interesting idea.  I do not have any such hardware, but I could imagine it being testable nevertheless.  I would recommend creating a section on how to test this without having a SnartNIC environment available.  I really think that will be essential for getting community assistance, as well as gate testing on commodity hardware.

Also, while the spec mentions that the neutron agent need not be on the same node as the OVS, it does not explicitly mention the next question many people will think of: does this also invalidate the one-to-one mapping of neutron agents to Open vSwitch processes?  It would be worthwhile to note that explicitly to draw a boundary around how much this is intended to change the architecture.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-24 00:15:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-24 00:37:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Spec for Neutron Remote OVS Agent

This spec describes the changes to Neutron to make Neutron OVS agent
can manage the OVS running remotely.

BP: remote-ovs-agent
Change-Id: Ie8967d7400fc40b08450f5c1eddb97cf085a3a4a

subject: Spec for Scalable Neutron OVS agent
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 333, 'name': 'Isaku Yamahata', 'email': 'isaku.yamahata@gmail.com', 'username': 'yamahata'}, {'_account_id': 4491, 'name': 'Lianhao Lu', 'email': 'lianhao.lu@intel.com', 'username': 'lianhao-lu'}, {'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 12171, 'name': 'Moshe Levi', 'email': 'moshele@nvidia.com', 'username': 'moshele'}, {'_account_id': 13995, 'name': 'Nate Johnston', 'email': 'nate.johnston@redhat.com', 'username': 'natejohnston'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jensås', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}, {'_account_id': 28373, 'name': 'Kailun Qin', 'email': 'kailun.qin@hotmail.com', 'username': 'kailun.qin'}, {'_account_id': 28692, 'name': 'Eyal Lavee', 'email': 'elavee@mellanox.com'}, {'_account_id': 28714, 'name': 'Adrian Chiris', 'email': 'adrianc@nvidia.com', 'username': 'adrianc'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-23 07:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-08-23 20:50:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

If I understand this spec correctly, you are creating a message router that will route messages destined for neutron-openvswitch-agent from RabbitMQ to the agent, as an additional piece of middleware.  I see adding an additional layer of hierarchical message routing as something that will add complexity and fragility.  A competing approach would be to change the existing neutron-openvswitch-agent so that it could handle N OVS processes directly, and not add any new process types handling the messaging.  It would probably be beneficial for you to compare and contrast the pros and cons of that approach - if you feel it is suboptimal I would be interested to hear why.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-24 03:06:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Nate, since there many fanout type rpc call/cast from Neutron ML2 plugin to OVS agent, reducing the number of OVS agent would improve the rabbitMQ performance. I'll add information about making OVS agent directly in another section as a further alternative enhancement in the next revision."}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-08-24 03:06:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-09-10 17:19:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Have you looked at OVN?  That manages many OVS instances with no RPC messaging, and therefore no bottleneck on RabbitMQ?  I think that would be a much better (and already existing) solution for this issue.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-09-10 23:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Proposals to help Neutron the scale up are always welcome and this one definitely are interesting. However, to move forward, we need a much more detailed spec and discussion.Probably, also a PoC'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-09-12 15:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Nate Johnston, it seems that OVN solves the problems and worth for us to investigation further. But our problem is that our customer has a specific requirement to use neutron OVS agent now.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:29:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Adding a note that came up in discussion in the PTG.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2018-09-14 03:53:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

i'll update this based on PTG discussion"}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-09-25 11:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-11-27 02:16:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

it has been many months since i reviewd this at intel and i wil give the same feedback i gave then. i agree that there is a scaling problem in neutron that we shoudl address but achitectually i think this i happening at the wrong level. we should IMHO try ot enable sharding of neutron in a driver independt way if possible rather then just addressing this usecase for ml2/ovs.

this is moveing ml2/ovs into a nova cellsv2 like deployment model
rather then adress scaling within the ml2/ovs mechdriver and agent specifically a driver indepent approch would be better?

having a generic mechanium to shard neutron's contol plane would be benifial for this usecase but also for edge deployments.

we have know for quite some time that the way the ml2/ovs mech driver interacts with the ovs agent hits scaling issues over ~2000 nodes
and that a distibuted state model such as the one used by ovn or kubernets scales better then the rpc approch. so directionally this could be good but i think if we move it up one level so that it can be optionally leveaged by all in tree ml2 backends such as sriovnicswitch or linuxbridge has merits."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

According to what we agreed during Shanghai PTG, I abandon this patch for now due to no activity. If You would be interested in continue work on this, feel free to restore the patch.'}]

Co-existence of netdev vnic and system vnic

This spec proposes a feature to support netdev vnic and system
vnic simultaneously for a virtual machine.

subject: [Spec] Reaction to network congestion for neutron qos
messages:
[{'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-01-16 09:41:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-01-16 13:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-01-16 16:11:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-01-19 08:38:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Fouad: can You maybe check https://review.openstack.org/#/c/445762 and talk with author of it to maybe merge somehow those two specs? Maybe I'm wrong but IMHO both are related to same feature but You want to do it in little bit different way :)"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-01-20 11:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-01-20 11:45:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I have also one more question. How You want to do it "together" with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/445762 ? Or maybe will should choose one solution which will be later implemented?'}, {'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-01-24 15:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-01-24 15:46:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)

For your question about https://review.openstack.org/#/c/445762. We already discuss this possibility, we think that our spec could be considered as a second part of the reedip one. Because his proposal is to activate ECN marking in routers and networks which are places among others in the architecture where ecn could be enabled. In general, the more ecn marking is activated in different places the more the mechanism will be efficient. Besides the ECN enablement which we do on OpenvSwitch in case the VMs do not activate it, we compute the congestion and react to it which is not in Reedip’s scope.
Please find below the rest of the answers:'}, {'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-01-24 15:48:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 26886, 'date': '2018-02-01 13:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-08-23 21:02:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:14:46.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

According to what we agreed during Shanghai PTG, I abandon this patch for now due to no activity. If You would be interested in continue work on this, feel free to restore the patch.'}]

commit_message:
[Spec] Reaction to network congestion for neutron qos

This spec proposes in three steps a congestion reaction
mechanism for overlays network:

- Ensure the ECN marking is enabled for all VMs.
- Compute the congestion threshold of tenants and VMs.
- React to the congestion by limiting VM's bandwidth ports.

Change-Id: Ia9702b52a1c4730d714b1a6860d723db79590fbd
Related-Bug: #1708460

implement automatic allocation of floating IPs in Neutron.

[{'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-08-24 02:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-08-24 02:47:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-08-24 02:50:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-08-29 16:06:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I do like having the option to re-balance resources, whether it be manual or automatic - I actually think we need to support a manual method be default since some operators will not want it to be automatic, in case it triggers a service outage while any migration is in progress.  I'll take a closer look at the spec, and have added a placeholder on the Stein PTG wiki to discuss this item as well.  Thanks Kailun."}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-08-31 02:51:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Brian, thanks a lot for raising the discussion in Stein PTG!
Indeed, I agree with you that the manual way of re-balancing resources is also indispensable when overloading. Let's keep updated on the PTG progress of this topic and see how to better move forward. :)"}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-09-10 21:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Brian/Miguel,
My colleague Ruijing Guo is at the Stein PTG this whole week. He is familiar w/ this bp/spec. He'll participate in most of the Neutron sections, especially the L3 and StarlingX sections where this topic is going to be further discussed.
Please do not hesitate to let him know whether you have any question or idea to discuss about so that we could better move forward. :) Much appreciate all your kind help."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-09-11 22:09:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

I still need to read the updated spec.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-09-11 22:24:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-09-12 03:05:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-09-12 07:11:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-09-12 07:14:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-09-12 07:19:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)

1. update some fixes;
2. add some use cases after investigating [1], they are all open for PTG discussion.

I'll add/remove use cases and update the implementation correspondingly based on the feedback/alignment. Thanks!

[1] https://github.com/openstack/osops-tools-contrib/blob/master/neutron/dhcp_agents_balancer.py"}, {'account_id': 15070, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Copy comments from PTG discussion

Router and DHCP server re-balancing (haleyb)

◾Operators need a way to either manually or automatically re-balance resources when controllers become overloaded

◾Failure can cause re-schedule to active agents, restoration can have an "empty" controller

◾A majority of active routers in an L3-HA deployment could end up on a single controller

◾Command similar to 'neutron-ovs-cleanup' ?

◾https://review.openstack.org/#/c/595978/ - StarlingX proposal

◾Initial thoughts from meeting

•Setting priority of routers in l3-ha deployment via keepalived settings could be used to automatically keep routers balanced

◦neutron could set this randomly or statically set such that each controller has a combination that should keep a balance during events

◦Concentrate on the HA case

•DVR centralized and legacy routers need a different solution

◦We'll leave this to be managed by a script approach

•For DHCP, using multiple agents for network should get us HA such that re-balancing should not be noticed

◦We'll leave this to be managed by a script approach

•It was mentioned that people that use scripts for this have run into problems moving too many things quickly (agent overloaded), so if this moved into the server it needs to take care doing this.

•Make sure everything in this block is properly documented'}, {'account_id': 15070, 'date': '2018-09-21 02:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Plan to write external script to do DHCP/L3 router rebalance.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-11-14 10:13:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

According to what we agreed during Shanghai PTG, I abandon this patch for now due to no activity. If You would be interested in continue work on this, feel free to restore the patch.'}]

commit_message:
Rescheduling of DHCP Servers and Routers

The distribution of DHCP servers and routers can sometimes be unbalanced
due to various causes. With the current Neutron implementation, no auto
mechanism is available to deal with this kind of situation.

This spec introduces a threshold based auto rescheduling mechanism for
DHCP servers and routers, which provides the benefit of balancing host
port allocations for DHCP servers, and CPU usage for routers.

Implements: blueprint rescheduling-of-dhcp-servers-and-routers
Change-Id: Id9eaf12cc8c606985af31b9beaabef2ee163a933

commit_message:
Support address-set in security-group-rules

This patch is a spec that describes a way to support specifying
a set of IP addresses in security group rules.

Change-Id: I4c4c2fe33ce616d163f0e9f18a743d2d214b2846
Related-Bug: #1649417

commit_message:
add-certificate-to-vpnaas

A proposal for vpnaas to extend auth_mode for certificate
by leveraging off different cert manager backend.
vpnass can use certificate for authentication in NAT schema.

Change-Id: I5d90efc29cb8a9a70fe4a29f3ed06c8e019c9d4e
Blueprint: add-certificate-to-vpnaas
Closes-Bug: #1459427

commit_message:
[WIP] First draft of L7 filtering extension

This spec intend to provide L7 filtering API for FWaaS V2.0.
L7 filtering API will be designed as a Extension API of Firewall
Plugin V2. Therefore, we can enable/disable if need. This API
allows tenant protect their web-application for each HTTP request.

A reference for HTTP filter driver base on eBPF will be provided.

Change-Id: I767d1986559b9624caa3141c227c9bb4f193b6db

[{'created': '2019-09-04 13:42:14.000000000', 'message': "Mark HPE 3PAR driver unsupported

The HPE 3PAR driver has failed to demonstrate Pyton3.7
support as was required during the Train release.  As
a result the driver is being marked unsupported and will
be removed in the 'U' release if support is not
demonstrated via 3rd Party CI.

Change-Id: Ia7c1cc17e8fe66295ff80ea744487f90f4f47382
"}]
commit_message:
Mark HPE 3PAR driver unsupported

The HPE 3PAR driver has failed to demonstrate Pyton3.7
support as was required during the Train release.  As
a result the driver is being marked unsupported and will
be removed in the 'U' release if support is not
demonstrated via 3rd Party CI.

Change-Id: Ia7c1cc17e8fe66295ff80ea744487f90f4f47382

subject: Mark Synology Driver Unsupported

commit_message:
Mark Synology Driver Unsupported

The Synology Driver 3rd Party CI hasn't
reported in over 100 days.  This does not meet the requirements
for Cinder's 3rd Party CI requirements.

As a result the driver is being marked unsupported in the
Train release and should be removed in the 'U' release if
the problems are not resolved.

Change-Id: I97d5ef06e8d80f463bfc4e393ed0e55cddf9a1c1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-12 08:49:33.000000000', 'message': 'Get rid of Mistral for listing validations

Until now, we were using Mistral to get all the validations available on
the Undercloud. This patch drops the Mistral support for the validations
listing through the CLI and will parse them directly on the filesystem
instead of parsing from the *tripleo-validations* Swift container.

This change makes the CLI faster:
- ~6s with Mistral
- ~1.3s w/o Mistral

Change-Id: I5730fb2e23775f1d666276b6b4d46bcb550fc928
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 746b97f19a67989f200365fa9ffc3df569091f2f)
'}]
commit_message:
Get rid of Mistral for listing validations

Until now, we were using Mistral to get all the validations available on
the Undercloud. This patch drops the Mistral support for the validations
listing through the CLI and will parse them directly on the filesystem
instead of parsing from the *tripleo-validations* Swift container.

This change makes the CLI faster:
- ~6s with Mistral
- ~1.3s w/o Mistral

Change-Id: I5730fb2e23775f1d666276b6b4d46bcb550fc928
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 746b97f19a67989f200365fa9ffc3df569091f2f)

commit_message:
Swift: parametrize rsyncd max connections

Max connections in rsyncd template used hardcoded values and this
commits allows to now customize them

It creates the variables:
* swift_rsyncd_max_connections_account
* swift_rsyncd_max_connections_container
* swift_rsyncd_max_connections_object

Change-Id: I095e489ed02c730c84b3490d0b77c831bee0992b
Closes-Bug: #1852095

commit_message:
Add groups.yaml containing Validation Groups definition

This file will be the source of reference for all the groups used by
tripleo-Validations. It will be deployed next to the playbooks/roles[1]
in order to parsed by the TripleO Validator CLI and its new
subcommand[2].

It will also be the reference for the tripleo-validations documentation
and will be automated in a follow up patch.

[1] - /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-validations/groups.yaml
[2] - openstack tripleo validator group list

Change-Id: I56b9d39c113cfb30695fe8cf2740ae147b0dd3e4

commit_message:
Limited retry until we no longer have collisions

In MP image uploader workers mode, some workers may end up as
defuncts leaving their locks on layers for ever.

Create a circuit breaker by limiting retries on locking busy
layers long enough to allow them normally being downloaded.

Change-Id: I91d9b930f5c85646530b6a847dde57ed978acdf1
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Prefer ovn_dbs_vip from all_nodes_extra_map_data

When all_nodes_extra_map_data includes a value for ovn_dbs_vip that
value should be preferred over any other. This fixes an issue in the
multi-stack case where the dependent stacks were using the wrong value
for the ovn vip.

Change-Id: Idf534e50d3a1ec879c340996ac225c80f4b52d3f
(cherry picked from commit a610cb132a5cea069fa54063e7de97fb25add8c2)

commit_message:
Requirements-check: use local repo like any other library

This ensures the playbook has done a local install of the repo so the
script run can assume that it is installed and can be loaded without
additional handling.

Change-Id: Iaf759b183e6821bf6690195586e7e65bf0533c82

commit_message:
Change the RPC parameter

The arg name in restore_backup of backup rpcapi is volume_host, but
actually we use backup.host. This is very easy to misunderstand, so
just change it to backup_host.

Change-Id: I3dbd21981a67bedb389ce12ac083c501073e846a

commit_message:
Update constraints for amqp to new release 2.5.2

Also update kombu to 4.6.6 that depends on amqp

This fixes a bug in amqp see this

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693704/
https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1852058

Change-Id: I68f640b4ec843e946047f25c37c5277f09de28d4

commit_message:
Remove puppet-module-unit-jobs from puppet-n1k-vsm

Puppet 4.8 is dead, this repo is the only user of the template.
Remove template.

This allows us to remove the project-template and associated jobs.

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/692640
Change-Id: I0bac132d35bc6b67da3dd176248c93d38fd2b0f5

With the introduction of Readiness/Liveness probes in

preventing successful armada manifest applies.

Add support to disable the probes.

Signed-off-by: Zhipeng Liu <zhipengs.liu@intel.com>

commit_message:
Neutron: Add support for disabling Readiness/Liveness probes

With the introduction of Readiness/Liveness probes in
Ib99ceaabbad1d1e0faf34cc74314da9aa688fa0a, some probes are failing and
preventing successful armada manifest applies.

Add support to disable the probes.

Change-Id: I61379a5e00de4311c02c3f64cbe7c7345a9b3569
Signed-off-by: Zhipeng Liu <zhipengs.liu@intel.com>

commit_message:
Enable ipv6 tempest tests with os_tempest

In fs035, we do IPv6 deployment. Upstream tempest has added
IPv6 related tempest tests as a part of train community goals[1.].
It enables the same and moves to os_tempest.

[1.] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Change-Id: I795512db3b98f1cb400e297bf7b3e5f0c07aeb96
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-12 20:48:21.000000000', 'message': 'Use the Mistral directory for storing the Ansible fact cache.

This aligns with how TripleO currently stores all Ansible data
in /var/lib/mistral/. Our documentation already recommends
running setfacl on that directory if an end-user wants to
access the files there.

Change-Id: I29d0a353cd0a0d28f36460a8e81003378884a5bd
Closes-Bug: #1850916
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Use the Mistral directory for storing the Ansible fact cache.

This aligns with how TripleO currently stores all Ansible data
in /var/lib/mistral/. Our documentation already recommends
running setfacl on that directory if an end-user wants to
access the files there.

Change-Id: I29d0a353cd0a0d28f36460a8e81003378884a5bd
Closes-Bug: #1850916
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

These are used as roles with include_role so having common.yaml

commit_message:
Move vars/common.yaml to main.yaml for buildimages and containers

These are used as roles with include_role so having common.yaml
brings no benefit since vars_from defaults to main.yaml.

So we can remove the explicit include_vars for common. First
noticed it working in [1] and then split this change as the parent
into its own review

[1] https://review.opendev.org/692985

Change-Id: Ia5c83f1bafc23d149bcc67d4af697f3af7aa976c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-31 14:21:50.000000000', 'message': 'Increase timeout when waiting for dnsmasq enablement

In the reported bug, a regression was introduced in [1] when limiting
the time to have a "dnsmasq" process enabled. It has been reported, as
documented in the bug, that in older versions (Queens), using Python 2
[2] and older versions of "ip_lib" (not implementing most of the
commands using Pyroute2), that the time needed to spawn a "dnsmasq"
process exceeds the default 60 seconds defined in
"common_utils.wait_until_true".

This patch increases this time by a reasonable 300 seconds.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643732
[2] https://bugs.python.org/issue35757

Change-Id: I2d8693145da72825876b951f2d10afe9ca28ff6e
Closes-Bug: #1849676
(cherry picked from commit aedc09917680bc77501f4b57142e73768e3d06ad)
'}]
commit_message:
Increase timeout when waiting for dnsmasq enablement

In the reported bug, a regression was introduced in [1] when limiting
the time to have a "dnsmasq" process enabled. It has been reported, as
documented in the bug, that in older versions (Queens), using Python 2
[2] and older versions of "ip_lib" (not implementing most of the
commands using Pyroute2), that the time needed to spawn a "dnsmasq"
process exceeds the default 60 seconds defined in
"common_utils.wait_until_true".

This patch increases this time by a reasonable 300 seconds.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643732
[2] https://bugs.python.org/issue35757

Change-Id: I2d8693145da72825876b951f2d10afe9ca28ff6e
Closes-Bug: #1849676
(cherry picked from commit aedc09917680bc77501f4b57142e73768e3d06ad)

subject: Pre-empt in-progress nested stack updates on new update
messages:
[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-10-23 22:17:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-10-24 01:22:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-10-24 02:38:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-10-24 14:01:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:
